Links I Find Interesting

A constantly updated stream of things I'm reading and find fascinating.



Reimagining the IoT. Remember this market is in it's infancy and everything is up for grabs! - 30 Jun 2016

In some ways the Internet of Things is already part of the fabric of our lives yet it feels unfulfilled and unsatisfying. Or maybe simply suffering from a lack of imagination.

The title is provocative and the writing is fresh but the deep insights into VR, technology and embodiment will stick with me for a while. (Mildly NSFW). - 30 Jun 2016

When I’m really honest with myself, I’m proud of what I did. Maybe it’s cause I felt like an explorer or an astronaut setting foot on an alien terrain. But when I’m really really honest with myself, I was just a guy sitting in the dark with a phone strapped to his face intentionally filling his pants with cum.

New (to me) - the Ezra Klein podcast. This episode with Andrew Sullivan is far-ranging, entertaining and also powerful. - 20 Jun 2016

I'm part way through this talk by Jen Simmons - Modern Layouts- Getting Out of Our Ruts. And now I'm lost in this wonderful rabbithole of web design inspiration labs.jensimmons.com. - 16 Jun 2016

From Dave Winer - Rivers are still the best way to get news on the web. Something I've been thinking about a lot recently. Follow Dave's new 1999.io project too... - 08 Jun 2016

In other words, there's an opportunity for the news industry to disrupt the tech industry. Not something the tech industry is going to be all that interested in you knowing about of course.

How promotion affects pageviews on the New York Times. Clear and fascinating analysis on normalizing pageviews to draw insights. Also an open source tool soon. - 07 Jun 2016

What emerges from this visualization is a clear picture of four distinct classes of content on the New York Times’ site - (A) Wire articles which never reached the homepage, (B) Original articles which never reached the homepage, (C) Wire content which is featured on the homepage for a short period of time, and (D) Original content which receives promotion on both the homepage and across social media. While groups A and B encompass a wide variety of outcomes, groups C and B generally display a positive linear relationship between time on homepage and pageviews.

One page dungeon 2016 winners. Sublime. - 06 Jun 2016

Seth Godin on the difference between the freelancer and the entrepreneur. - 05 Jun 2016

The trap is simple - Sometime freelancers get entrepreneur-envy and start hiring other freelancers to work for them. This doesn’t scale. Managing freelancers is different from being a freelancer. Managing freelancers and saving the best projects for yourself gets you into trouble. The cash flow gets you into trouble. Investors don’t want to invest in you because you can’t sell out if you’re a freelancer at heart

Sean Blanda on The Creative World’s Bullshit Industrial Complex & my optimistic take on an alternative. - 04 Jun 2016

Deeply thought provoking, a portrait of the artist as a young mom. As new parents I'm thinking a lot about how to keep a creative practice for both of us, but especially for the Mum. - 27 May 2016

Her experience of sacrifice and loss might seem extreme, but among the women I spoke with, it wasn’t uncommon. What was more unusual were women who were willing to talk about ways in which they accepted that their devotion to art made them, at least at times, less of a parent. One of those was writer and mother Zoe Zolbrod. Like me, she has two children. Like me, she is about to publish a book she struggled to write through the early years of motherhood. We talk about the various challenges of writing, parenting, working a day job, stealing time. “The truth,” she says, “is that I think I’m a better mom when I’m not writing. I’m not writing right now and I’m enjoying the kids more. I’m better at home when I’m writing less.”

Ben Thompson on Stratechery Peter Thiel, Comic Book Hero. - 26 May 2016

From this perspective, it could not be more perfect that Thiel made the largest part of his fortune by investing in Facebook, where he still sits on the board. Facebook specifically and the Internet broadly has made it possible for sensationalistic rags like Gawker to exist, even as it has fundamentally weakened journalism by destroying the geographic monopolies that guaranteed the financial freedom to comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable. Thiel as the personification of the tech industry is very much the superhero looking to remedy a problem he created.

A smart opinion on the state of agencies and management consulting in 2016 - 23 May 2016

The ad industry has a talent, lifestyle, and purpose problem. Behind the generation of career-coasting marketers maintaining business as usual sits a frustrated, hungry, product focused, and purpose driven generation of progressives. For anyone working in and around agencies and brands those generational fault lines are clear to see.

I did an interview with Dan Shure on my SEO history, working for Google and more. - 21 May 2016

A nice overview of the challenges facing news organizations in 2016. (Especially love the "paragraph as navigation" UI.) - 20 May 2016

A smart take on the state of the media industry, The Facebook Papers - 19 May 2016

Native advertising, the overladen vehicle upon which so many of publishers hopes now rest, faces the same challenges in an atomized content world. When working as intended, native advertising is commercial content intended to elicit the same user experience as the editorial content that surrounds it. In an atomized world, no editorial content surrounds it. It exists alone in the stream, adrift from the content it was intended to mimic.

With that unbundling, the only economic purpose for a site that makes its living from native advertising to create content other than native advertising is to maintain its brand. This means that the media company becomes a native advertising creative agency with an absurdly expensive brand marketing department formerly known as the newsroom.
